reasoning: [Specific Program Not Verified] Paper mentions 'Citizens Damage Compensation (Watan Card) Program' but search could not confirm this as graduation program: Perplexity search result: The Citizens' Damage Compensation (Watan Card) Program in Pakistan was implemented as an emergency response following the 2010 monsoon floods. It focused on the rapid distribution of cash grants using debit cards ('Watan Cards') to flood-affected families. Multiple authoritative sources confirm that the program provided unconditional cash transfers or grants (PKR 20,000-40,000 in phases) to beneficiaries, using bank cards for disbursement[1][2][3][5]. There is no evidence in program documentation or evaluations that productive assets—such as livestock, tools, or business capital—were provided. Graduation-type programs are characterized by a sequenced package of support, typically including asset transfers, training, coaching, and cash support with a long-term focus on sustainable livelihoods for the ultra-poor. The Watan Card/CDCP was an emergency, single-component cash relief program, not a multi-component or graduation intervention, and did not include livelihood, asset transfer, or capacity-building elements[1][2][3]. | Graduation: NO, Cash: YES, Assets: NO | Confidence: HIGH | Sources: https://www.gfdrr.org/sites/default/files/Pakistan%20Citizens%20Damage%20Compensation%20Program%20(CDCP).pdf, https://documents1.worldbank.org/curated/en/153031468139211888/pdf/806210WP0P12680Box0379812B00PUBLIC0.pdf, https://www.rspn.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/BB-National_Report_CDCP_Final.pdf
